children.subject:
Yeah, I realized after reading a lot on Piazza that ML theory is wayyyyy different than having ML in your toolbox to apply to a problem. 

Just curious, how did you find Data 100 and 188? I'm planning on taking one of the two next semester–which one was more worthwhile?

Looking at the classes in isolation, I think 100 is much more useful because it teaches you practical DS (and a little ML) skills which will be relevant for industry whereas 188 teaches you mostly outdated AI concepts most of which won't be industry-relevant and if you're interested in ML, it only covers the basics for a few weeks.
Ya I think I'm going with 100, especially since Josh Hug is teaching it next sem!!! The syllabus also seems more practical (data cleaning, etc).

I'm in a similar boat. I've taken C100 and 188 and I'm now taking 182 and 189. I enjoy 182 since it covers cool modern DL stuff and in 189 I enjoy coding up models & working with data but dislike the math derivations. I'm currently working part-time at a startup doing applied ML/DL & SWE: data cleaning, feature engineering, optimizing models, and deploying them.

I don't have an answer for you, but I am curious as to what others say considering most discussions among students tend to revolve around which ML/DL/math classes to take (which are theoretical and academic) + making ML useful in industry involves more than just the model (which is often created with standard ML/DL libraries), i.e. creating the infrastructure to support it.

history.content:
So I'm not crazy about math (did fine in my math classes, just not the kind of person to read math textbooks or papers) and definitely prefer systems and coding over theory. That being said, the applications of machine learning really interest me (i.e. detecting tumors, doing cool computer vision stuff, etc). 

What sort of coursework, research opportunities, or other avenues should I use to explore these interests? Also, given that I'm not planning on doing ML research in grad school, would 189 alone be sufficient, or should I also consider EE126/127? I know Prof. Sahai strongly recommends them to get a really in depth understanding of ML, but I'm not necessarily looking to being an ML researcher. I'm looking to apply ML to other areas that interest me (sports, music, etc).

Thanks!
history.subject: Applied ML
